describption: Early advertisements showed families how to turn Maple Leaf flour bags into clothing, promoting creative reuse during a time when resources were limited.
Magazines highlighted DIY, mending, and patchwork styles as the environmental movement grew.
International news exposed unethical factory conditions, pushing sustainability and ethics into mainstream media for the first time.

tite: Media Covers Fast Fashion’s Hidden Costs
describption: After global outsourcing expanded, journalists began reporting on cheap production, textile waste, and environmental harm.
News outlets worldwide investigated fashion’s supply chains, making sustainability a mainstream issue.
Creators began posting sewing tutorials, thrift flips, and clothing repair hacks — making sustainable fashion accessible and trendy for millions online.
Posts about thrift hauls and sustainable styling boosted awareness of resale fashion.
Viral thrift flips and DIY repair videos introduced millions to sustainable practices.

tite: Media Pushes Circularity as the Future
describption: Articles highlight textile recycling, resale markets, and rental platforms as industry standards.
